chordBuilder.title: Chord Builder
chordBuilder.description: Select intervals to build a chord. The result updates in real time.
chordBuilder.harmonicOverlapHint: Green bars = overlapping harmonics. Click to hear individual harmonics.
chordBuilder.waveformHint: Combined waveform of all chord tones. Consonant chords produce smoother, more periodic patterns.
chordBuilder.noThird: No 3rd selected. The 3rd determines whether a chord is major or minor.
chordBuilder.dominant7th: Dominant 7th: major 3rd for brightness, perfect 5th for stability, minor 7th for tension.
chordBuilder.major7th: Major 7th: the combination of major 3rd and major 7th gives a smooth, jazzy quality.
chordBuilder.majorTriad: Major triad: the major 3rd sets the bright quality, the perfect 5th adds stability.
chordBuilder.minor7th: Minor 7th: minor 3rd for the dark quality, perfect 5th for grounding, minor 7th for added color.
chordBuilder.minorTriad: Minor triad: the minor 3rd gives the darker quality, the perfect 5th provides grounding.
chordBuilder.diminished: Diminished: both the minor 3rd and diminished 5th create instability. Tends to resolve strongly.
chordBuilder.augmented: Augmented: major 3rd with augmented 5th. Unstable and ambiguous.
chordBuilder.majorNoFifth: Major 3rd present but no perfect 5th. Adding the P5 would ground the chord.
chordBuilder.minorNoFifth: Minor 3rd present but no perfect 5th. Adding the P5 would ground the chord.
chordBuilder.defaultMessage: The 3rd determines major/minor quality, the 5th provides stability, 7ths add color.

frequencyPlot.title: Frequency Visualization
frequencyPlot.linearExplanation: Frequency grows exponentially: each fret multiplies by 2^(1/12). The curves bend upward because equal musical intervals correspond to increasingly large Hz gaps.
frequencyPlot.logExplanation: In log scale, the lines become perfectly straight. Each fret is the same musical distance (1 semitone) despite being a different frequency distance. This is why cents (a log-based unit) are used to measure tuning.
frequencyPlot.bothExplanation: The left chart (linear) shows exponential frequency growth. The right chart (log) shows the same data as straight lines. The log view matches how pitch is perceived: each fret is the same musical distance even though the Hz gaps grow.
frequencyPlot.clickHint: Click any point to hear the note. Lines are parallel because each string follows f(n) = f‚ÇÄ √ó 2^(n/12).

circleOfFifths.title: Circle of Fifths
circleOfFifths.description: Click any note to select that key. Clockwise = up a perfect 5th.
circleOfFifths.refAdjacentKeys: Adjacent keys differ by one note (smooth modulation)
circleOfFifths.refIIVV: I-IV-V are always adjacent on the circle
circleOfFifths.clickHint: Click any chord button to hear it.

intervalExplorer.fretboardPatternText: Every <note1>{{note1}}</note1>-<note2>{{note2}}</note2> pair on the fretboard forms the same interval ({{intervalName}}). The shape is identical regardless of position.
intervalExplorer.veryConsonant: Very consonant - simple frequency ratio. Your brain recognizes this pattern easily.
intervalExplorer.consonant: Consonant - pleasant and stable. Commonly used in harmony.
intervalExplorer.moderatelyConsonant: Moderately consonant - some tension but still pleasant.
intervalExplorer.dissonant: Dissonant - creates tension that wants to resolve.
intervalExplorer.veryDissonant: Very dissonant - complex ratio creates strong tension.

harmonicSeries.title: Harmonic Series
harmonicSeries.description: Select a root note to see its overtone series. Lower harmonics produce the most consonant intervals.
harmonicSeries.clickHint: Click any bar to hear that harmonic.
harmonicSeries.harmonicRatiosText: The lowest harmonics correspond to simple ratios: 2:1 (octave), 3:2 (perfect fifth), 5:4 (major third). These ratios produce strong overtone overlap and sound consonant. Higher harmonics have more complex ratios and add brightness and tension.

harmonicOverlap.title: Harmonic Overlap
harmonicOverlap.description: Compare the harmonic series of two notes. More overtone alignment means more consonance.
harmonicOverlap.waveformHint: Combined waveform of both frequencies. Consonant intervals produce smoother, more periodic patterns.
harmonicOverlap.harmonicAlignmentHint: Green = overlapping harmonics (within 50 cents). Click to hear individual harmonics.
harmonicOverlap.consonanceStrong: Strong harmonic alignment. The overtone series of both notes overlap significantly, producing a stable, consonant sound.
harmonicOverlap.consonanceGood: Good harmonic overlap. Stable with some tonal color.
harmonicOverlap.consonanceModerate: Moderate overlap. Some tension present alongside stability.
harmonicOverlap.consonanceLimited: Limited harmonic overlap. The beating between misaligned overtones creates audible tension.
harmonicOverlap.consonanceMinimal: Minimal overlap. Strong tension from clashing overtones.

centsCalculator.title: Cents Calculator
centsCalculator.description: Compare two frequencies and measure the distance in cents. 1 semitone = 100 cents, 1 octave = 1200 cents.
centsCalculator.ref5cents: ¬±5 cents: Barely noticeable to human ear
centsCalculator.ref100cents: 100 cents: One semitone (e.g., C to C#)
centsCalculator.ref1200cents: 1200 cents: One octave (e.g., C4 to C5)

scaleExplorer.noFavorites: No favorite scales yet. Tap the heart icon on any scale to save it.

chordVoicingFinder.noVoicingsFound: No voicings found with current constraints. Try increasing the max fret span.

progressionBuilder.selectTemplate: Select a template to get started

progressionExplorer.title: Trunk-Based Progression Explorer
progressionExplorer.maxTrunks: Max trunks reached. Remove a trunk to add more.
progressionExplorer.instructions: + on a node = see suggestions. Click a suggestion to add it. Yellow dot = expandable leaf. Purple = root. Blue = trunk. Max 5 trunks.
progressionExplorer.noSavedProgressions: No saved progressions yet. Build a progression and save it from practice mode!

melodyExplorer.hintSelected: Click a note to edit. Click the background to deselect.
melodyExplorer.hintUnselected: Click a card to select it.
melodyExplorer.emptyTitle: Set a key and scale, then generate melody paths.
melodyExplorer.emptyDescription: Four paths, each with a different movement style. Select one to edit or practice.

chordFrequencyChart.title: Chord Frequency Distribution
chordFrequencyChart.top10Summary: Top 10 chords = {{value}}% of all occurrences in {{genre}}. Click any bar to hear the chord.

genreFingerprintsChart.title: Genre Fingerprints
genreFingerprintsChart.selectHint: Select up to 4 genres to compare across 5 harmonic dimensions.
genreFingerprintsChart.chordDiversity: Chord Diversity: number of commonly used chords.
genreFingerprintsChart.dominantUsage: Dominant Usage: frequency of 7th, sus, dim, aug chords.
genreFingerprintsChart.predictability: Predictability: concentration of transitions in top choices.
genreFingerprintsChart.chromaticColor: Chromatic Color: usage of altered and extended chords.

transitionHeatmap.clickToHear: Click any row to hear the transition.
transitionHeatmap.clickCell: Click a cell to hear the transition.

gCentricUniverse.title: The G-Centric Universe
gCentricUniverse.hoverHint: Hover for connections. Click to play.
gCentricUniverse.nodeSizeDescription: Node size = frequency in {{genre}}. Edge thickness = transition probability. On hover, edges color by harmonic movement: <blue>blue</blue> = resolution (4th up), <orange>orange</orange> = tension (5th up), <green>green</green> = lateral.
